bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Truby requests that Hench keep the information he provided on Agramonte confidential.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Sept. 12/40

div1.p:
I am returning your mms. under
separate cover to day. I have made you
a sketch of the hospital grounds which is
fairly accurate, but not drawn to scale,
as I have no exact knowledge of the
distances on size of buildings. If you
want to use it, I suggest that you have
it done over, more expertly-

You will find my notes in ink on
the mms. and on the questionaire. This was
the best I could do as I am going away
for a week or so and could not find time
to have it all typed. In the end this way
will probably be as easy for you, as you
can, I think, pick out the items you want
and dictate them to your secy-

Please consider anything I have said
about the statements re. Agramonte as Confidential,
until I hear what Kean and others want
to do about that. The matter has come up
often and always we have decided not
to bring the matter up unless it became
necessary to do so.

When Kean returns my mms. I will
send it on to you so you can see
Ac
T
what I have written. The article
will need much going over and
I will probably cut out much of my
personal part in the work, if it is ever
published. I have no plans about its
publication and will be glad to get your
views on that point when you have time
to consider it.

I would like to get a copy (without numbers)
of the small photo. of the hospital (Photo 10),
I have one, taken a little earlier, before
the building at the left (your no. 1.) was erected.
I have kept some of the photos. and thank
you very much for them.

It has been a real pleasure to
work up the info. you wanted and
I feel sure you will find it fairly
accurate. The whole subject is
intensely interesting to me and from
the amount of time you have spent in
working on it, I can see how interested
you have become.

closer.seg:
P. S. Kissinger was a fine young soldier
and was always reliable. If you see
him again please tell him so-
A E T
